subject: Gardening
title: Focal Points and the Eye's Journey
description: A micro-lesson that makes Focal Points and the Eye's Journey usable.

hook.text: Without a focal point, the eye wanders. With one, the entire garden organizes itself around a single anchor.

buildup.text: A focal point is any element that commands attention: a specimen tree, sculpture, bench, water feature, or bold plant.

discovery.text: Effective focal points sit at the end of sight linesâ€”where paths lead, where axes cross, where the eye naturally rests.

twist.text: Too many focal points cancel each other out. One strong element per view is the rule. Restraint is the designer's skill.

climax.text: A focal point gives a garden purpose. It says: look here first, then explore outward from this anchor.

punchline.text: One focal point organizes an entire garden view.

quiz.question: What happens when a garden has too many focal points?
options: The garden becomes more exciting and dynamic
They cancel each other out and the eye has nowhere to rest
Extra focal points create a sense of mystery and discovery
